awd_titl_txt: Core Activities of the Committee on Science, Engineering, and Public Policy (COSEPUP)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award to the National Academies will provide partial support for the core activities of the Committee on Science, Engineering and Public Policy (COSEPUP). COSEPUP has a charge 'to deliberate on initiatives for new studies in the area of science and technology policy, taking especially into account the concerns and requests of the President's Science Advisor, the Director of the NSF, the Chairman of the National Science Board, and the chairmen of key science and technology-related committees of the Congress.' Its work has addressed issues of critical importance to Federal Agencies and the Nation. 

Key issues that COSEPUP is addressing or has recently addressed include maintaining the excellence of human resources for U.S. science and engineering research, promoting effective management of U.S. federal research investments, and ensuring research integrity and the responsible conduct of research. Since its inception, the National Science Foundation has supported COSEPUP activities. This award will provide funds for core support of COSEPUP, to continue its work as an independent advisor on issues relating to national science and technology policy.

por.por_cntn:
The Committee on Science, Engineering, Medicine, and Public Policy (COSMEPUP) of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) continually surveys the science, engineering, and medical landscape to identify challenges and opportunities and then provide insight and guidance to relevant decision makers, including the National Academies' presidents, agency leaders, and members of Congress.  The committee's mandate remains the same as when it was established in 1961: "to deliberate on initiatives for new studies in the area of science and technology policy, taking especially into account the concerns and requests of the President's Science Advisor, the Director of the NSF, the Chairman of the National Science Board, and the chairmen of key science and technology-related committees of the Congress."

The members of COSEMPUP are drawn from the most senior and experienced individuals in the U.S. research community.  The committee's bi-annual meetings and other core capabilities allow it to track and respond to key issues affecting the health of the U.S. research enterprise over time. 

During the life of the current of the current award, COSEMPUP has produced a range of products aimed at producing broad positive impacts on the U.S. research enterprise.  These include "Fostering Integrity in Research" (see https://www.nap.edu/catalog/21896/fostering-integrity-in-research), a 2017 consensus study that examines challenges to scientific integrity facing the research enterprise and recommends steps that individual scientists, research sponsors, research institutions, journal publishers, and professional societies should take to meet these challenges and better protect integrity in research.  The same year, the committee published the proceedings of a workshop on using data and narrative to communicate the value of science (see https://www.nap.edu/catalog/24695/using-narrative-and-data-to-communicate-the-value-of-science). The workshop examined how to merge the insights of expert judgment and newly available quantitative data and present them in engaging narratives that will capture the interest of policymakers and the public.  More recently, COSEMPUP contributed to the 2019 report "Reproducibility and Replicability in Science" (see https://www.nap.edu/catalog/25303/reproducibility-and-replicability-in-science), which defines reproducibility and replicability and examines the factors that may lead to non-reproducibility and non-replicability in research.

In February 2020, the National Academy of Sciences hosted, with the participation of COSEMPUP members, a symposium on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of Vannevar Bush's "Science - The Endless Frontier."  At the event, leaders from science, government, academia, business and philanthropy met to reflect on Bush's legacy and explore new approaches for addressing the challenges and opportunities of the next 75 years.  An event proceedings is available on the event webpage (see https://www.nationalacademies.org/event/02-26-2020/the-endless-frontier-the-next-75-years-in-science).

In July 2020, COSEMPUP convened a workshop entitled "Reopening U.S. Research Universities: Confronting Long-Standing Challenges and Imagining Novel Solutions" to explore the key questions the research enterprise must address to build a more effective and resilient 21st century research university.  A proceedings of the workshop was published by the National Academies Press (see https://www.nap.edu/catalog/25947/reopening-us-research-universities-confronting-long-standing-challenges-and-imagining-novel-solutions).  The workshop is envisioned as a precursor to a series of workshops on issues that arose during discussions at the July workshop including: 1) the future of the public research university; 2) enabling new career paths (from education to training to mentoring and employment) for the graduate workforce; 3) responding to research integrity challenges and opportunities highlighted because of the pandemic; 4) re-imagining international collaboration and cooperation; 5) envisioning the research laboratory of the future; and 6) reshaping the research enterprise to respond more effectively to global challenges.

In late July 2020, the Academies' Intelligence Community Studies Board launched, in collaboration with COSEMPUP, a new study on the Intelligence Community and the Science and Technology Research Environment. 

In the fall of 2020, the Academies' Board on Science, Technology, and Economic Policy and Committee on Science, Technology, and Law, in collaboration with COSEMPUP, launched a study on Protecting Critical Technologies for National Security in an Era of Openness and Competition. 

At the request of National Academy of Sciences President Marcia McNutt, COSEMPUP assisted with the development of a mission statement for a proposed Strategic Council for Research Integrity.  The Council would be convened to assist in safeguarding the health and welfare and elevating the excellence of the whole research enterprise. 

The committee is engaged in ongoing discussions with NSF, White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, and National Institutes of Health leadership in discussions about policies, strategies, and tools to mitigate against potential threats to U.S. national security and economic leadership.  Section 1746 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2020 (Public Law 116- 92) charged the Academies to convene a standing national science, technology, and security roundtable.  This roundtable was established in September 2020 and will provide, for a period of five years, a neutral venue where individuals from the national intelligence and law enforcement communities can meet with representatives from industry and the academic research community to discuss current threats, benefits, and potential risks.
